title: Everton move a step closer to securing a new stadium as developers vow to make the Liverpool waterfront a 'visual spectacle'
text:
Sport Everton move a step closer to securing a new stadium as developers vow to make the Liverpool waterfront a 'visual spectacle' The Merseyside club are believed to be in advanced talks with developer Peel who say a deal is close to being finalised Share Bramley Moore Dock is the proposed site for Everton's new home (Photo: Liverpool Echo) Share Get football   Thank you for subscribing!   
Everton could be moving a step closer to securing a new stadium after developer Peel said a deal is close to being finalised and a ‘state-of-the-art’ ground would make the Liverpool waterfront a ‘visual spectacle'. 
According to the Liverpool Echo, the Merseyside club are believed to be in advanced talks with Peel, who own the northern docklands and are developing it under the £5.5bn Liverpool Waters scheme. 
Mayor Joe Anderson fuelled speculation over the deal even more on Monday night when he suggested on Twitter that the move was close to being finalised for the Bramley-Moore docks site. Bramley Moore Dock could become a visual spectacle (Photo: Liverpool Echo) Read More Romelu Lukaku's refusal to sign new Everton contract is 'not an issue' 
And today, speaking at the Mipim property festival in Cannes, Lindsey Ashworth, development director at Liverpool Waters for Peel, said: “We're optimistic we will agree heads of terms to allow a state-of-the-art football stadium at the northern end of the Liverpool Waters. Maybe even Commonwealth Games. 
“I cannot say how excited we all are.” 
Mr Ashworth told the ECHO: “We're in quite healthy talks with Everton at the moment, so it's not finalised yet. But as Peel and as myself I would love to see a stadium on the waterfront. 
“To have this as the anchor at one end of the waterfront, and then you go all the way down towards the ECHO arena... the waterfront would be a visual spectacle. Everton are set to have a new state-of-the-art ground (Photo: Liverpool Echo) 
“So we're pushing forward with it, the council are helping, and I think we'll get to a conclusion. A good one. Hopefully in the near future.” 
Heads of terms is an initial agreement ahead of signing a full contract. 
Peel's other plans for the northern docks, including floating buildings, will be changed if the stadium happens. Goodison Park has been the home for Everton for over 120 years (Photo: Liverpool Echo) 
He said: “At the northern docks, Bramley-Moore Dock and Nelson Dock, we have two options. 
“One is to develop it out with several developers for residential and put floating buildings in the docks themselves. And the floating buildings would be doctors' surgeries, workshops, bars, restaurants.
